title: Newcomerâ€™s Guide into Optimal Data Acquisition for Electron Ptychography
content: Electron ptychography is a unique method enabling low-dose high-contrast imaging at a considerable range of magnifications via computational phase/amplitude retrieval from diffraction data [1, 2]. For the computational reconstruction of the image contrast from the acquired diffraction patterns, numerous data acquisition parameters, such as camera length, probe semi-convergence angle, scanning step size, etc. must be calibrated and then carefully chosen for optimal imaging conditions. The combinations suitable to a specific experiment may not be intuitively clear for newcomers to the field and lead to suboptimal or even wrongly acquired datasets.
